name: Systems DSA (The C Foundation)
description: Intensive 25-week Systems DSA bootcamp focused on C language for semiconductor/embedded systems interviews at Nvidia, Qualcomm, NXP, and Google Silicon. Covers pointers, memory, bit manipulation, data structures with hardware context including registers, UART, SPI, and RTOS concepts. Theme: 'Memory is a Flat Line' - understanding that variables are physical addresses in SRAM.

topics.name: Week 1: The Physics of C (Pointers & Memory)
topics.description: Master & (Address of) and * (Value at). Understand that arr[i] is syntax sugar for *(arr + i). Semiconductor context: Sensors dump data into linear buffers that cannot be resized. Passing a 1MB image buffer by pointer takes 4 bytes instead of copying.
learningTip: In C, YOU control memory - no garbage collector, no safety net
Pointers are just variables holding memory addresses (4 bytes on 32-bit, 8 bytes on 64-bit)
arr[i] is syntactic sugar for *(arr + i) - understand this equivalence deeply
Every pointer bug becomes a segfault or silent corruption - master pointers completely
Drill: Write swap(int *a, int *b) from scratch - understand pointer dereferencing
Drill: Write strlen(char *s) using pointer arithmetic only
Drill: Write memcpy(void *dest, void *src, size_t n) from scratch
Project: Memory Alignment Drill - Create struct with char, int, char. Verify sizeof is 12 bytes (padding). Use #pragma pack(1) to force 6 bytes. Proves Data Bus Width knowledge.
mustNotMiss: & (address-of): Gets memory address. int x = 5; int *p = &x; // p holds address of x
* (dereference): Gets value at address. *p = 10; // changes x to 10
Pointer arithmetic: p+1 moves by sizeof(*p) bytes, not 1 byte. int* increments by 4 bytes
void* is the universal pointer - can hold any address but cannot be dereferenced directly
Always initialize pointers: int *p = NULL; prevents undefined behavior

practiceQuestions.name: Find the Integer Added to Array

topics.name: Week 2: Prefix Sums (Time vs. Space)
topics.description: Pre-calculating running totals for O(1) range queries. Semiconductor context: Telemetry & Battery - calculate total energy consumed between t=100ms and t=500ms without iterating the loop every time.
learningTip: Pre-compute running totals for O(1) range queries
Trade-off: O(n) space and build time for O(1) query time
Critical for telemetry: 'What was total energy between t=100ms and t=500ms?'
In embedded, CPU cycles are precious - precompute what you can
mustNotMiss: Build: prefix[i] = prefix[i-1] + arr[i] with prefix[0] = arr[0]
Query: sum(l, r) = prefix[r] - prefix[l-1] (handle l=0 edge case)
C code: int prefix[n]; prefix[0] = arr[0]; for(int i=1; i<n; i++) prefix[i] = prefix[i-1] + arr[i];
Watch for integer overflow in cumulative sums - use int64_t for safety
Pattern extends to 2D: compute row prefix, then column prefix for O(1) rectangle sums

topics.name: Week 3: The Two-Pointer Technique (Static)
topics.description: Using left and right indices to scan buffers from both ends in O(n) instead of O(n²). Semiconductor context: Buffer Compaction - remove dead bytes (zeros) without creating new array (In-Place algorithm).
learningTip: Two pointers avoid O(n²) nested loops by moving intelligently
Sorted array: left from start, right from end - O(n) for pair finding
Fast/slow: detect cycles, find middle in one pass
This pattern appears in 40%+ of array/string problems
mustNotMiss: Pair sum in sorted array: if sum < target, move left++; if sum > target, move right--
Fast/slow for linked list: fast = fast->next->next; slow = slow->next; - cycle if they meet
Remove duplicates: slow writes, fast scans - maintain invariant that [0..slow] has unique elements
Partition: swap with two pointers from ends - foundation for QuickSort
C pattern: int left = 0, right = n-1; while(left < right) { ... left++; ... right--; }

topics.name: Week 4: 2D Arrays (Matrices)
topics.description: Mapping Row-Major [i][j] coordinates to linear memory addresses. Semiconductor context: Image Sensors & Displays - camera frames are 2D pixel matrices for ROI processing.
learningTip: 2D arrays in C are contiguous memory - int arr[R][C] is R*C integers in a row
Row-major order: arr[i][j] = *(arr + i*COLS + j) - understand the address calculation
Cache locality matters: row-major iteration is 10-100x faster than column-major
Image buffers, sensor grids, lookup tables - 2D arrays are everywhere in embedded
Drill: Why row-major iteration is faster than column-major (cache locality)
Project: Write two functions to sum 1024x1024 int matrix - Row-Major vs Column-Major. Measure execution time difference. Understand CPU cache behavior.
mustNotMiss: Memory layout: int arr[2][3] = {{1,2,3},{4,5,6}} stored as [1,2,3,4,5,6] contiguously
Access: arr[i][j] = *((int*)arr + i*COLS + j) - pointer decay when passed to function
Row-major iteration: for(i) for(j) is cache-friendly; for(j) for(i) causes cache misses
Passing to function: void f(int arr[][COLS], int rows) - column size must be compile-time constant
Or use: void f(int *arr, int rows, int cols) and access arr[i*cols + j]

topics.name: Week 5: Basic Boolean Logic
topics.description: Master & (Clear/Check), | (Set), ^ (Toggle), ~ (Flip), << (Shift). HIGHEST ROI section - in Embedded C, you control hardware by writing to 32-bit Registers. Set Bit 5 to turn on LED, read Bit 3 to check button press. Changing the wrong bit crashes the system.
learningTip: Bit manipulation is THE core skill for embedded/firmware engineering
Hardware registers are 32-bit words where each bit controls something
Set bit 5 = turn on LED. Read bit 3 = check button state. Wrong bit = system crash
Think in binary: 0x1F = 0001_1111 = bits 0-4 set. Visualize the bit pattern
Project: Write is_little_endian() function - detect system endianness
Project: SWAP_ENDIAN(x) macro - Flip 32-bit integer using shifts
Project: Write SET_BIT(reg, n), CLEAR_BIT(reg, n), TOGGLE_BIT(reg, n), CHECK_BIT(reg, n) macros - the building blocks of all firmware
mustNotMiss: SET bit n:   reg |= (1 << n)     // OR with 1 at position n
CLEAR bit n: reg &= ~(1 << n)    // AND with 0 at position n (invert mask)
TOGGLE bit n: reg ^= (1 << n)    // XOR flips the bit
CHECK bit n: (reg >> n) & 1      // Shift to LSB, mask with 1. Returns 0 or 1
Create mask for bits m to n: ((1 << (n-m+1)) - 1) << m
Example: GPIO_PORT |= (1 << LED_PIN); // Set LED pin high

topics.name: Week 6: Advanced Bit Hacks
topics.description: Using masks to pack/unpack data. Semiconductor context: Packet Headers - a single 32-bit integer stores [Version: 4 bits][Length: 8 bits][Type: 4 bits][ID: 16 bits]. Extract using shifts and masks.
learningTip: Pack multiple fields into single integer - save memory, save bandwidth
Packet headers: 32 bits = [Version:4][Length:8][Type:4][ID:16]
Extract field: mask and shift. Insert field: clear, shift, and OR
Bitfields exist in C but are implementation-dependent - prefer manual bit ops
Project: Parse a 32-bit packet header - extract Version (bits 28-31), Length (bits 20-27), Type (bits 16-19), ID (bits 0-15)
mustNotMiss: Extract bits m to n from x: (x >> m) & ((1 << (n-m+1)) - 1)
Set bits m to n to val: x = (x & ~mask) | ((val << m) & mask)
Swap without temp: a ^= b; b ^= a; a ^= b; // XOR swap trick
Check power of 2: (n & (n-1)) == 0 && n > 0
Count set bits (fast): while(n) { n &= n-1; count++; } // Brian Kernighan's algorithm
Isolate lowest set bit: n & (-n) // returns power of 2

practiceQuestions.name: Prime Number of Set Bits in Binary Representation
Number of Steps to Reduce a Number to Zero

topics.name: Week 7: Math & Number Theory
topics.description: Modulo arithmetic, GCD, Primes. Semiconductor context: Timers & Clocks - calculate divisor for 80MHz clock to 9600 baud rate. Cryptography relies on Primes and GCD.
learningTip: GCD, primes, modular arithmetic appear in checksums, crypto, hashing
Euclidean GCD: gcd(a,b) = gcd(b, a%b) until b=0
Modular arithmetic: (a + b) % m = ((a%m) + (b%m)) % m - prevents overflow
Prime checks: trial division up to sqrt(n) is O(sqrt(n))
mustNotMiss: GCD iterative: while(b) { int t = b; b = a % b; a = t; } return a;
LCM: lcm(a,b) = a * b / gcd(a,b) - but compute as a / gcd(a,b) * b to avoid overflow
Overflow-safe modular multiply: ((a%m) * (b%m)) % m
Sieve of Eratosthenes for all primes up to n: O(n log log n)
Fast power: x^n in O(log n) using repeated squaring

topics.name: Week 8: Review & Floating Point
topics.description: Review hardest Bit Manipulation problems. Project: Manual IEEE 754 Parser - proves understanding of how hardware stores decimals. Deep dive into floating point quirks.
learningTip: IEEE 754: sign(1) + exponent(8) + mantissa(23) for 32-bit float
Floats have precision issues: 0.1 + 0.2 != 0.3 in binary floating point
In embedded: avoid float for timing-critical code, fixed-point is often better
Comparison: use epsilon tolerance, never compare floats with ==
Project: IEEE 754 Parser - C function that takes float and prints sign, exponent, mantissa bits
Project: Implement fixed-point multiplication for Q16.16 format
mustNotMiss: float: ~7 significant digits. double: ~15 significant digits
Comparison: fabs(a - b) < epsilon instead of a == b
Infinity: 1.0/0.0 = inf. NaN: 0.0/0.0 = nan. Check with isnan(), isinf()
Fixed-point alternative: store mV as int (1234 = 1.234V) - no float HW needed
Casting: (int)3.7 = 3 (truncates toward zero)

topics.name: Week 9: String Parsing (UART Context)
topics.description: Handling char arrays without standard libraries. Semiconductor context: AT Commands - ESP32 WiFi module sends '+WIFI:CONNECTED', need to parse this string to know state. Data arrives byte-by-byte via UART or SPI.
learningTip: C strings are null-terminated char arrays - no built-in length tracking
String functions: strlen, strcpy, strcat, strcmp, strstr - know their complexity
Buffer overflow is #1 security vulnerability - always check bounds
Protocol parsing: extract fields from byte streams using pointers
Project: State Machine Parser - Parse stream byte-by-byte, trigger 'Command Found' only when exact sequence \r\nOK\r\n is detected
Project: Implement a simple AT command parser that handles: AT, AT+RST, AT+CWJAP="ssid","pass"
mustNotMiss: Null terminator: char s[] = "abc" is actually 4 bytes: {'a','b','c','\0'}
Safe copy: strncpy(dest, src, sizeof(dest)-1); dest[sizeof(dest)-1] = '\0';
Parse number: int n = 0; while(*s >= '0' && *s <= '9') n = n*10 + (*s++ - '0');
Find char: char *p = s; while(*p && *p != target) p++; // p points to target or \0
Compare: strcmp returns <0, 0, >0 for less, equal, greater

practiceQuestions.name: First Unique Character in a String

topics.name: Week 10: Fixed Sliding Window
topics.description: Window of size k moves across array. Semiconductor context: Moving Average Filter - smooth noisy temperature sensor by averaging last 10 readings. Foundation of Digital Signal Processing.
learningTip: Fixed window: maintain sum/data of exactly k elements
Slide by removing left element, adding right element - O(1) per slide
In embedded: moving average filters for sensor smoothing
Pattern: initialize window, then slide maintaining invariant
Project: Implement a moving average filter in C with configurable window size
mustNotMiss: Initialize: for(int i=0; i<k; i++) windowSum += arr[i];
Slide: for(int i=k; i<n; i++) { windowSum = windowSum - arr[i-k] + arr[i]; update_max(); }
Moving average: avg = windowSum / k; uses integer division by default in C
Deque for min/max in window: O(n) total for all elements
Fixed window always has exactly k elements - simpler than dynamic

practiceQuestions.name: Find All Anagrams in a String
Maximum Number of Vowels in a Substring

topics.name: Week 11: Dynamic Sliding Window
topics.description: Window expands and shrinks based on data validity. Semiconductor context: Debouncing - look for longest continuous window of 'High' signals to confirm button press.
learningTip: Dynamic window: grow right, shrink left based on condition
Find longest/shortest subarray satisfying constraint
Pattern: expand right, then contract left while condition holds
Time: O(n) - each element enters and exits window at most once
mustNotMiss: Template: for(right=0; right<n; right++) { add arr[right] to window; while(invalid) { remove arr[left]; left++; } update_answer(); }
Longest subarray with sum ≤ K: shrink while sum > K
Shortest subarray with sum ≥ K: update answer inside the while loop
Character frequency: int freq[256] = {0}; freq[(unsigned char)s[i]]++;
Track distinct count: if(freq[c] == 0) distinct++; freq[c]++;

practiceQuestions.name: Maximize the Confusion of an Exam
Count Complete Subarrays in an Array

topics.name: Week 12: Buffer Review & Fixed-Point Arithmetic
topics.description: Re-solve hardest Sliding Window problems. Challenge: Implement Moving Average without float/double for FPU-less microcontrollers. Real embedded constraint.
learningTip: Review and solidify Month 3 concepts before moving to data structures
Focus on: pointer arithmetic, two-pointer, sliding window patterns
In embedded: buffers are everywhere - data acquisition, communication, logging
Practice implementing standard library functions from scratch
Project: Fixed-Point Arithmetic - Re-implement Moving Average without float/double
mustNotMiss: Implement memcpy: while(n--) *dest++ = *src++;
Implement memmove: handle overlap by copying backward if dest > src
Implement strrev: two pointers swap from ends
Circular buffer: if(++head >= SIZE) head = 0; // or head = (head+1) % SIZE
Review: what's the complexity? What's the space? Can we do better?

topics.name: Week 13: Singly Linked Lists (Basics)
topics.description: Manipulating next pointers. Semiconductor context: OS Kernel (FreeRTOS/Linux) manages processes using Linked Lists - the 'Ready Queue' is a Linked List of tasks waiting to run.
learningTip: Linked list = dynamic data structure with O(1) insert/delete at known position
Node structure: struct Node { int data; struct Node *next; };
In embedded: used for dynamic queues, memory pools, event lists
Draw the pointers before coding - most bugs are incorrect pointer updates
Project: Implement a simple task queue using linked list with add_task() and get_next_task()
mustNotMiss: Create node: struct Node *n = (struct Node*)malloc(sizeof(struct Node)); n->data = val; n->next = NULL;
Insert at head: newNode->next = head; head = newNode;
Delete node: prev->next = curr->next; free(curr);
Traverse: while(curr != NULL) { process(curr); curr = curr->next; }
ALWAYS free() what you malloc() - memory leaks crash embedded systems
Sentinel/dummy node simplifies edge cases: struct Node dummy; dummy.next = head;

practiceQuestions.name: Delete Node in a Linked List

topics.name: Week 14: Advanced Lists (Cycles & Doubly Linked)
topics.description: prev and next pointers. Cycle detection. Semiconductor context: Deadlock Detection - if Task A waits for Task B and vice versa, you have a cycle. Tortoise and Hare algorithm detects this.
learningTip: Doubly linked: O(1) delete with just the node pointer, bidirectional traversal
Reverse, merge, detect cycle - core linked list patterns
LRU cache = hashmap + doubly linked list
In embedded: task lists, memory allocators, undo buffers
Project: No-Malloc Pool - Pre-allocate array of 100 Nodes, write alloc_node() and free_node() functions (Automotive safety-critical pattern)
mustNotMiss: Reverse: prev=NULL, curr=head; while(curr) { next=curr->next; curr->next=prev; prev=curr; curr=next; } return prev;
Detect cycle (Floyd's): slow=fast=head; while(fast && fast->next) { slow=slow->next; fast=fast->next->next; if(slow==fast) return true; }
Find cycle start: after detection, reset slow=head, advance both by 1 until meet
Merge sorted: dummy head, compare and link smaller, handle remaining tail
Doubly linked delete: if(n->prev) n->prev->next = n->next; if(n->next) n->next->prev = n->prev; free(n);

practiceQuestions.name: Remove Nth Node From End of List

topics.name: Week 15: Stacks (LIFO)
topics.description: Last In, First Out. Semiconductor context: Nested Interrupts - CPU pushes context to stack when ISR fires, pops it back when done. Stack overflow causes Hard Fault.
learningTip: Stack: LIFO - Last In First Out
Used for: function calls (call stack), expression evaluation, undo, DFS
Array implementation: O(1) push/pop, fixed size
Understanding call stack is essential for debugging and recursion
mustNotMiss: Array stack: int stack[SIZE]; int top = -1;
Push: if(top < SIZE-1) stack[++top] = val; else overflow_error();
Pop: if(top >= 0) return stack[top--]; else underflow_error();
Peek: if(top >= 0) return stack[top];
In C: function calls use stack - local variables, return addresses stored there
Stack overflow: recursion too deep, or large local arrays - use static/heap instead

practiceQuestions.name: Remove All Adjacent Duplicates In String

topics.name: Week 16: Monotonic Stacks
topics.description: Finding the 'Next Greater Element'. Semiconductor context: Telemetry Spikes - finding next time temperature exceeds current threshold. Critical for alerting systems.
learningTip: Monotonic stack: maintain increasing/decreasing order for next greater/smaller element
Pop smaller/larger elements when new element arrives - they found their answer
O(n) total: each element pushed and popped at most once
Pattern solves: next greater, previous greater, stock span, largest rectangle
Project: Implement a peak detector that finds the next time a sensor reading exceeds a threshold
mustNotMiss: Next greater element: stack stores indices, decreasing order of values
When arr[i] > arr[stack[top]], pop and set answer[popped] = arr[i]
Template: for(i=0; i<n; i++) { while(top>=0 && arr[stack[top]] < arr[i]) ans[stack[top--]]=arr[i]; stack[++top]=i; }
Remaining in stack have no next greater - set answer to -1
Previous greater: same logic but iterate from right or use different condition

topics.name: Week 17: Circular Queues (CRITICAL)
topics.description: Fixed array that wraps around using Modulo %. THE #1 MOST USED structure in firmware - connects hardware (UART) to software. Master this completely.
learningTip: Queue: FIFO - First In First Out. Circular queue wraps around fixed array
Ring buffer is THE most common data structure in embedded systems
In embedded: UART buffers, sensor data, interrupt-safe producer-consumer
Fixed size, no malloc - perfect for constrained environments
Project: Implement a full UART RX circular buffer with: enqueue (called from ISR), dequeue (called from main), is_empty, is_full, available_space
mustNotMiss: Structure: struct CircQueue { int data[SIZE]; int front, rear, count; };
Enqueue: if(count < SIZE) { data[rear] = val; rear = (rear+1) % SIZE; count++; }
Dequeue: if(count > 0) { val = data[front]; front = (front+1) % SIZE; count--; return val; }
Empty: count == 0. Full: count == SIZE
ISR-safe single producer/consumer: producer only writes rear, consumer only writes front - no lock needed
volatile for shared variables: volatile int front; - prevents compiler optimization

practiceQuestions.name: First Unique Character in a String

topics.name: Week 18: Heaps (Priority Queues)
topics.description: Accessing Min or Max element in O(1). Semiconductor context: RTOS Event Scheduling - 'Run Task A in 5ms, Task B in 2ms'. Min-Heap organizes timer events by expiry time.
learningTip: Heap = complete binary tree with heap property, stored in array
Min-heap: parent ≤ children. Max-heap: parent ≥ children
O(1) get-min/max, O(log n) insert and extract
Used for: priority queues, heapsort, top-k, scheduling
Project: Implement a timer event queue using min-heap - add_timer(callback, delay_ms), tick()
mustNotMiss: Array indexing: parent(i) = (i-1)/2, left(i) = 2*i+1, right(i) = 2*i+2
Insert (heapify-up): add at end, while child < parent: swap with parent
Extract (heapify-down): swap root with last, remove last, bubble down swapping with smaller child
Build heap in O(n): start from last parent ((n-1)/2), heapify-down each
In C: int heap[SIZE]; int size = 0; // implement push(), pop(), peek()
Heapsort in-place: build max-heap, repeatedly extract to end of array

practiceQuestions.name: Kth Largest Element in a Stream

topics.name: Week 19: Hash Maps & Sets
topics.description: O(1) lookup using keys. Semiconductor context: Device Whitelisting - checking if Bluetooth MAC address is authorized. Symbol tables for debuggers.
learningTip: Hash table trades space for O(1) average lookup
In C: implement with array + linked list (chaining) or open addressing
For embedded: often use perfect hashing or direct arrays when key range is known
Understanding collision resolution is essential for system reliability
Project: Implement an LRU cache for firmware config parameters
mustNotMiss: Hash function: h(key) = key % TABLE_SIZE - choose prime TABLE_SIZE
Chaining: struct Entry { int key; int val; struct Entry *next; }; Entry *table[SIZE];
Open addressing: linear probing h(k,i) = (h(k) + i) % SIZE - watch for clustering
Load factor α = n/SIZE: keep α < 0.75 for chaining, α < 0.5 for open addressing
In embedded: fixed arrays when key range bounded, perfect hash when keys known
String hash: h = 0; while(*s) h = h * 31 + *s++; return h % SIZE;

topics.name: Week 20: Binary Trees (BFS/DFS)
topics.description: Hierarchical data nodes. Semiconductor context: Filesystems (FAT/LittleFS), device trees, interrupt hierarchies. Understanding recursive traversal.
learningTip: Trees model hierarchical data: file systems, parse trees, decision trees
Recursion is natural: each subtree is itself a tree
In embedded: expression parsing, protocol state machines, config hierarchies
Stack space for recursion is limited - know max depth or use iterative
Project: Calculate exactly how much stack memory Merge Sort uses for 1M elements
mustNotMiss: Node: struct TreeNode { int val; struct TreeNode *left, *right; };
Traversals: Preorder (root-L-R), Inorder (L-root-R), Postorder (L-R-root)
Recursive inorder: void inorder(Node *n) { if(!n) return; inorder(n->left); process(n); inorder(n->right); }
Iterative with stack: push, go left, pop, process, go right
Height = 1 + max(left_height, right_height); base: height of NULL is 0 (or -1 depending on convention)
BST property: left < root < right for all nodes - inorder gives sorted sequence

practiceQuestions.name: Kth Smallest Element in a BST (Medium)

topics.name: Week 21: Graphs (DFS/BFS)
topics.description: Visiting nodes in a network. Semiconductor context: State Machines (FSM) - device moves from Init → Idle → Active → Error. Network topology analysis.
learningTip: Graph = vertices + edges. Trees are connected acyclic graphs
Representations: adjacency matrix O(V²), adjacency list O(V+E)
BFS for shortest path in unweighted, DFS for connectivity and cycles
In embedded: state machines, network topology, dependency graphs
Project: Traffic Light Controller FSM - States (RED, YEL, GRN), Events (TIMER, BTN), switch-case transitions. This IS firmware.
mustNotMiss: Adjacency matrix: int adj[V][V]; adj[i][j] = 1 if edge i→j
Adjacency list in C: int adj[V][MAX_EDGES]; int adj_count[V]; or linked lists
BFS: queue-based, O(V+E), finds shortest path in unweighted graphs
DFS: stack/recursion-based, O(V+E), for connectivity, cycles, topological sort
Topological sort: DFS post-order reversed, or Kahn's BFS with in-degree
Cycle detection: DFS with 3 states (WHITE/GRAY/BLACK) - cycle if visit GRAY

topics.name: Week 22: Dynamic Programming (1D)
topics.description: Solving sub-problems once. Semiconductor context: Path Optimization - finding most power-efficient route for packet in mesh network. Resource allocation.
learningTip: DP = recursion + memoization (or bottom-up tabulation)
Key insight: optimal solution uses optimal solutions to subproblems
Identify: overlapping subproblems + optimal substructure
In embedded: minimize memory with 1D DP or rolling array when possible
mustNotMiss: Top-down: recursive with memo - if(memo[n] != -1) return memo[n]; return memo[n] = compute(n);
Bottom-up: fill table from base cases - often more cache-friendly
State: what parameters define a subproblem? These become array dimensions
Transition: how does dp[i] depend on smaller subproblems?
Space optimization: often only need previous row - dp[2][n] or dp[n] with careful ordering
Common patterns: Fibonacci, Knapsack, LCS, Edit Distance, Longest Increasing Subsequence

practiceQuestions.name: Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock

topics.name: Week 23: Hard Problems (The Capstone)
topics.description: Deep focus sessions: 3-4 hours per problem. These are the problems that separate senior engineers from juniors. Expect to struggle. Each problem requires multiple attempts.
learningTip: Hard problems combine multiple techniques
Pattern recognition from previous weeks is key
Time pressure: 45 min for medium, 60 min for hard
Don't panic - break problem into smaller parts
mustNotMiss: Start with brute force, then optimize
Common optimizations: sorting, hashing, binary search, two pointers
If stuck: try different data structure, work backwards from answer
Test edge cases: empty input, single element, maximum size
Analyze: What's the complexity? Can we do better theoretically?
For embedded: mention memory constraints, no malloc, interrupt considerations

topics.name: Week 24-25: Mock Interviews (Whiteboard Mode)
topics.description: Two full weeks of intensive mock interview practice. No IDE. No Google. Paper and Pen only. This is how real interviews work. Practice speaking your logic out loud. Aim for 2-3 problems per day.
learningTip: Practice under time pressure - simulate real interview conditions
Communicate your thought process clearly
Start with brute force, discuss trade-offs, then optimize
For embedded roles: always mention memory, real-time, power considerations
mustNotMiss: Clarify: input size, constraints, edge cases BEFORE coding
Think aloud: 'I'm considering a hashmap for O(1) lookup because...'
Test with examples, including edge cases
Analyze complexity: 'This is O(n) time, O(1) space'
Embedded context: 'In a real system, I'd consider memory footprint, cache behavior, ISR safety'
Know projects on resume cold - be ready to go deep on anything listed
